Niskayuna water alert is not over yet
NISKAYUNA — The entire town is under a boil-water advisory after a massive water main break Thursday night on Mohawk Road that weakened pressure throughout the town, Supervisor
The advisory is in effect ""at least through the next couple of days,"" the supervisor said.
The 20-inch main ruptured between 8 and 9 p.m., prompting a rush of water that undermined sections of the street and flooded at least one basement at the base of the hill, Landry said.

Between midnight and 1 a.m., crews were able to isolate the break and worked throughout the night to repair it, Landry said. While water is returning to those who lost it, pressure may be reduced throughout the town, which is why the Schenectady County Department of
column5: query=%22Public+Health+Services%22"">Public Health Services recommended the boil-water advisory, he said.

column1: Landry said the main is one of the largest in the town and comes from the water plant at nearby Lock 7 along the Mohawk River.

The exact cause of the break is often impossible to know, Landry said, adding that recent fluctuations between warm and freezing temperatures could be to blame. Even the oldest water mains in town date only to the 1960s, Landry said.
""We had a slice in the pipe that may have been caused by the freeze-thaw cycle, but we don't know,"" he said. ""Within less than 12 hours, we had it fully repaired.""
Landry said sections of Mohawk Road also will likely remain closed for at least a day while crews repair the water damage.
""Whenever you have a water main break of that size, certain portions of the road end up washing away or sinking,"" Landry said.

<a class=""pr"" data-tncms-track-dmp=""Social Media Share"" data-tncms-track-event='{""app"":""editorial"",""metric"":""social_share"",""id"":6e100046-5bf6-11e2-922f-001a4bcf887a}' data-track='{""network"":""Print"",""socialAction"":""print"",""url"":""/news/local/moultrie-water-district-boil-order-lifted/article_6e100046-5bf6-11e2-922f-001a4bcf887a.html""}' href=""javascript:window.print()"" rel=""nofollow"" title=""Print"">
SULLIVAN - A boil order issued for customers of the Moultrie County Rural Public Water District has been lifted.
An announcement from the district said the boil order was lifted on Saturday. The order was issued on Friday because of a water main break north of the Sullivan water plant.

Posted January 11, 2013 08:43 am          - Updated January 11, 2013 08:53 am
Boil order issued for water main break in Aiken
<!-- Sets shortStory JS variable for DFP targeting -->

Two large water main breaks in Aiken have prompted a boil water advisory for some residents.

According to a news release, the Deerwood neighborhood from Pine Log Road to Troon Way and Woodside Plantation from Steeplechase Road to West Pleasant Colony Drive and Anderson Pond Road are under a boil water advisory until 24 hours after service has been restored.

For more information, contact City of Aiken Engineering and Utilities at (803) 642-7610.

syncHistLen is the array length of the Syncronex viewed content cookie. Each page visited represents 2 items in the array: the page URL and an internal value.
Because this function is invoked before the paymeter fires, the value of SyncHistLen is always one page short of the actual count.
The page on which the final STOP lightbox fires is not added to the history cookie.
Calculating the length of this cookie after one page viewed results in an undefined variable in this function.
A syncHistLen value of 4 is actually the third page view (4/2+1=3).  A syncHistLen value of 10 is actually the sixth page view (10/2+1=6).
A value of yes in syncAllow means there is no paymeter overlay on the screen.

Birmingham Waters Works lifts boil water advisory for Graysville, Adamsville, West Jefferson area
Madison Underwood | MUnderwood@AL.com
Email the author | Follow on Twitter
'title':'Birmingham Waters Works lifts boil water advisory for Graysville, Adamsville, West Jefferson area',
'desc': '\""The water is safe to drink through the entire service area, and the water quality will be monitored continually.\"" --Birmingham Water Works Board',
BIRMINGHAM, Alabama -- The Birmingham Water Works Board has lifted a boil water alert issued Wednesday for residents along Highway 78.

The advisory went into effect Wednesday due to a broken 16-inch water main along Highway 78 near Forestdale. The broken main caused a loss of pressure, and prompted the alert. The water is now safe to drink, according to a Water Works Board press release:

""Rigorous testing has been conducted to verify the safety of the drinking water, and all bacteriological samples from the boil water alert area have come back negative,"" the release stated. ""The water is safe to drink through the entire service area, and the water quality will be monitored continually.""

On Wednesday, the Birmingham Water Works Board warned residents of Adamsville, Graysville, Brookside and West Jefferson to boil any water to be used for drinking. That warning also applied to the following neighborhoods:

Forestdale

Forestview Estates

Hazelwood

Hillview

Huntington Hills

Pratt City communities off of Pratt Highway

Republic

Sandusky

Union Grove

Westwood


And to residents along the following streets (including streets adjacent to):

Blackmon Circle

Cedarcrest Drive

Cherry Avenue, west of Brandy Lane

Heflin Avenue

Tomahawk Drive

Tower Drive

Trailridge Drive

U.S. 78 west of Chickasaw Drive
As of 10 a.m. Friday, the boil water advisory is no longer in effect.

<a class=""pr"" data-tncms-track-dmp=""Social Media Share"" data-tncms-track-event='{""app"":""editorial"",""metric"":""social_share"",""id"":f177957c-5b68-11e2-bb0b-001a4bcf887a}' data-track='{""network"":""Print"",""socialAction"":""print"",""url"":""/news/rowesville-under-boil-water-advisory/article_f177957c-5b68-11e2-bb0b-001a4bcf887a.html""}' href=""javascript:window.print()"" rel=""nofollow"" title=""Print"">

The City of Orangeburg Department of Public Utilities, as a precautionary measure, advises the water customers of the Town of Rowesville, located in Orangeburg County, to vigorously boil their water for at least one full minute prior to cooking or drinking.
Also, any residents near the affected area who have lost water and/or water pressure are also advised to vigorously boil their water for at least one full minute prior to cooking or drinking.

The Water Division has experienced a 12-inch water main break along Rowesville Road. Water customers should continue to vigorously boil their water for at least one full minute prior to cooking or drinking until otherwise notified by Orangeburg DPU.
The Orangeburg DPU Water Division is presently working to correct the problem. Should you have any questions pertaining to this advisory, please call the Water Division at 803- 268-4401.

UPDATE: The boil advisory will be lifted at 1:15pm Thursday afternoon. Water Works officials say the water wasn't contaminated during the water main break. Water tests have come back negative for bacteria.

COUNCIL BLUFFS (KPTM)- Council Bluffs should know around noon Thursday if the city-wide boil advisory will have to go on for another day. People are being asked to boil water before consuming it until the advisory is lifted.

The advisory was put in to place Wednesday morning following a water main break in a neighborhood near 9th Street and Avenue E.
{\/p}

Some homes in the area were flooded after 3 million gallons of water was lost within an hour. This caused a drop in water pressure. Officials say bacteria could have gotten into the water but that the risk is very low.
{\/p}

Water Works employees collected water samples from different parts of the city Wednesday.
They have to be incubated for 24 hours. If the samples are clean Thursday afternoon they should be an amber color. If samples are contaminated they will be a purple color.
{\/p}

People like Rita Benson are following the boil order. She boiled pots of water on Wednesday. {\/p}

\""I got up and my dogs needed water, so I boiled it for them when I heard about it on the news.\""{\/p}

Benson suffers from arthritis and MS, so it's a lot harder for her to haul pots of water from her sink to her stove.{\/p}

\""Just lifting it and getting it into a container, it's harder on me than it would be for someone else.\""{\/p}

But she wants to be safe rather than having to worry. \""I'm not going to take any chances with myself or my animals.\"" So she'll keep boiling water until the city says it's safe not to. {\/p}

\""It really does make you appreciate it, a lot.\""{\/p}

If you have questions about the boil order you're asked to call 712-328-4672.{\/p}""}

Boil Advisory Lifted in Council Bluffs
column2:
body=You%20should%20read%20this!%0A%0Ahttp://fox42kptm.com/archive/boil-advisory-following-water-main-break-in-council-bluffs"">

UPDATE: The boil advisory will be lifted at 1:15pm Thursday afternoon. Water Works officials say the water wasn't contaminated during the water main break. Water tests have come back negative for bacteria.

COUNCIL BLUFFS (KPTM)- Council Bluffs should know around noon Thursday if the city-wide boil advisory will have to go on for another day. People are being asked to boil water before consuming it until the advisory is lifted.

The advisory was put in to place Wednesday morning following a water main break in a neighborhood near 9th Street and Avenue E.

Some homes in the area were flooded after 3 million gallons of water was lost within an hour. This caused a drop in water pressure. Officials say bacteria could have gotten into the water but that the risk is very low.

Water Works employees collected water samples from different parts of the city Wednesday.
They have to be incubated for 24 hours. If the samples are clean Thursday afternoon they should be an amber color. If samples are contaminated they will be a purple color.

People like Rita Benson are following the boil order. She boiled pots of water on Wednesday.

""I got up and my dogs needed water, so I boiled it for them when I heard about it on the news.""

Benson suffers from arthritis and MS, so it's a lot harder for her to haul pots of water from her sink to her stove.

""Just lifting it and getting it into a container, it's harder on me than it would be for someone else.""

But she wants to be safe rather than having to worry. ""I'm not going to take any chances with myself or my animals."" So she'll keep boiling water until the city says it's safe not to.

""It really does make you appreciate it, a lot.""

If you have questions about the boil order you're asked to call 712-328-4672.

Boil water advisory lifted in Laurie
A Laurie Public Works crew and construction workers repair a water main break on Route O at Hibdon Rd. Jan. 8.
The boil water advisory issued by the City of Laurie was lifted Thursday morning after test results showed no contamination following a water main break along Route O late Tuesday afternoon.

The boil water advisory issued by the City of Laurie was lifted Thursday morning after test results showed no contamination following a water main break along Route O late Tuesday afternoon.
Water service was shut off in southern Laurie shortly before 4 p.m. Jan. 8 after a contractor laying natural gas lines drilled through the six-inch water line main on Route O at the intersection with Hibdon Rd.
While service was restored in a few hours, it was recommended that users boil the water before consumption until test results came back clear.
The city recently had another water main break in this area. A 90-degree elbow fitting in the line at Hibdon Rd. and Route O failed Sunday, Dec. 30.
The new man-made break was located about 100 yards from the previous fitting failure, according to Young.
A temporary boil advisory was issued at that time as well until test results showed negative for contamination about four days later.

Several boil-water advisories issued throughout state

<a class=""fb"" data-new-window-height=""300"" data-new-window-width=""500"" data-tncms-track-event='{""app"":""editorial"",""metric"":""social_share"",""id"":94317b64-65a2-59a3-a01d-cdfea3e9377a}' data-toggle=""new-window"" data-track='{""network"":""Facebook"",""socialAction"":""post"",""url"":""/news/several-boil-water-advisories-issued-throughout-state/article_94317b64-65a2-59a3-a01d-cdfea3e9377a.html""}' href=""https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wvgazettemail.com%2Fnews%2Fseveral-boil-water-advisories-issued-throughout-state%2Farticle_94317b64-65a2-59a3-a01d-cdfea3e9377a.html%3Futm_medium%3Dsocial%26utm_source%3Dfacebook%26utm_campaign%3Duser-share"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""Share on Facebook"">

<a class=""fb"" data-new-window-height=""300"" data-new-window-width=""500"" data-tncms-track-event='{""app"":""editorial"",""metric"":""social_share"",""id"":94317b64-65a2-59a3-a01d-cdfea3e9377a}' data-toggle=""new-window"" data-track='{""network"":""Facebook"",""socialAction"":""post"",""url"":""/news/several-boil-water-advisories-issued-throughout-state/article_94317b64-65a2-59a3-a01d-cdfea3e9377a.html""}' href=""https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wvgazettemail.com%2Fnews%2Fseveral-boil-water-advisories-issued-throughout-state%2Farticle_94317b64-65a2-59a3-a01d-cdfea3e9377a.html%3Futm_medium%3Dsocial%26utm_source%3Dfacebook%26utm_campaign%3Duser-share"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""Share on Facebook"">

CHARLESTON, W.Va. -- The Department of Health and Human Resources has issued several boil-water advisories throughout the state. The advisories were issued either for a failure to properly monitor the drinking water, the lack of a properly certified operator, inadequate disinfection of the drinking water or inadequate operator coverage.Customers in the areas listed below should boil their water for at least one full minute prior to use until further notice. The affected areas include:Fayette County: Kanawha Falls Community Water Association.Greenbrier County: Black Bear Lodge and Browns Water System.McDowell County: 3 Way Super Stop Water System
column4: and the O'Toole Water System.Mercer County: Pinacle Water Association, Windmill Gap Water System
column6: and Weyanoke Giatto Water System. Raleigh County: Marfork Coal Company Office and Marfork Coal Slip Ridge Mine.Summers County: Rivers Rest Home Owners Association and The Village at Rock Ridge.Wyoming County: Green Camp Public Service District
column8: Pierpoint Public Service District Water System
column9: and Coal Mountain Public Service Water District.

Boil water advisory issued for parts of Wilmington rescinded

column3: }

column1: WILMINGTON, NC (WECT) - The Cape Fear Public Utility Authority rescinded a previously-issued precautionary boil water advisory on Thursday.
The advisory was issued after a contractor conducting work in the area hit a CFPUA water line, according to officials.
The advisory had covered all residents on Warlick Dr. to include 5020 through 5044, Holly Tree and Weston Ct., Gorham Ave., Montford Dr. and Whitner Dr.

The boil-water advisory issued Tuesday afternoon for residents along Kimberly Road, Dogwood Drive, North Hills Court, North Hills Drive and Laurel Street has been rescinded effective immediately, according to the city of New Bern.

The boil-water advisory issued Tuesday afternoon for residents along Kimberly Road, Dogwood Drive, North Hills Court, North Hills Drive and Laurel Street has been rescinded effective immediately, according to the city of New Bern.



Colleen Roberts, New Bern's public information officer, said the water system has been repaired and testing indicates the water is safe to drink.

UPDATE: The boil advisory will be lifted at 1:15pm Thursday afternoon. Water Works officials say the water wasn't contaminated during the water main break. Water tests have come back negative for bacteria.

COUNCIL BLUFFS (KPTM)- Council Bluffs should know around noon Thursday if the city-wide boil advisory will have to go on for another day. People are being asked to boil water before consuming it until the advisory is lifted.

The advisory was put in to place Wednesday morning following a water main break in a neighborhood near 9th Street and Avenue E.
{\/p}

Some homes in the area were flooded after 3 million gallons of water was lost within an hour. This caused a drop in water pressure. Officials say bacteria could have gotten into the water but that the risk is very low.
{\/p}

Water Works employees collected water samples from different parts of the city Wednesday.
They have to be incubated for 24 hours. If the samples are clean Thursday afternoon they should be an amber color. If samples are contaminated they will be a purple color.
{\/p}

People like Rita Benson are following the boil order. She boiled pots of water on Wednesday. {\/p}

\""I got up and my dogs needed water, so I boiled it for them when I heard about it on the news.\""{\/p}

Benson suffers from arthritis and MS, so it's a lot harder for her to haul pots of water from her sink to her stove.{\/p}

\""Just lifting it and getting it into a container, it's harder on me than it would be for someone else.\""{\/p}

But she wants to be safe rather than having to worry. \""I'm not going to take any chances with myself or my animals.\"" So she'll keep boiling water until the city says it's safe not to. {\/p}

\""It really does make you appreciate it, a lot.\""{\/p}

If you have questions about the boil order you're asked to call 712-328-4672.{\/p}""}

Boil Advisory Lifted in Council Bluffs
column2:
body=You%20should%20read%20this!%0A%0Ahttp://fox42kptm.com/archive/boil-advisory-following-water-main-break-in-council-bluffs"">

UPDATE: The boil advisory will be lifted at 1:15pm Thursday afternoon. Water Works officials say the water wasn't contaminated during the water main break. Water tests have come back negative for bacteria.

COUNCIL BLUFFS (KPTM)- Council Bluffs should know around noon Thursday if the city-wide boil advisory will have to go on for another day. People are being asked to boil water before consuming it until the advisory is lifted.

The advisory was put in to place Wednesday morning following a water main break in a neighborhood near 9th Street and Avenue E.

Some homes in the area were flooded after 3 million gallons of water was lost within an hour. This caused a drop in water pressure. Officials say bacteria could have gotten into the water but that the risk is very low.

Water Works employees collected water samples from different parts of the city Wednesday.
They have to be incubated for 24 hours. If the samples are clean Thursday afternoon they should be an amber color. If samples are contaminated they will be a purple color.

People like Rita Benson are following the boil order. She boiled pots of water on Wednesday.

""I got up and my dogs needed water, so I boiled it for them when I heard about it on the news.""

Benson suffers from arthritis and MS, so it's a lot harder for her to haul pots of water from her sink to her stove.

""Just lifting it and getting it into a container, it's harder on me than it would be for someone else.""

But she wants to be safe rather than having to worry. ""I'm not going to take any chances with myself or my animals."" So she'll keep boiling water until the city says it's safe not to.

""It really does make you appreciate it, a lot.""

If you have questions about the boil order you're asked to call 712-328-4672.

column1: <div class="" withRelated right"" id=""WNStoryBody""><span id=""WNStoryDateline"">BIRMINGHAM, AL (WBRC) -
The boil water alert issued for thousands of people in west Jefferson County has been lifted. The Birmingham Water Works Board officially ended the alert at 10 a.m. Friday, Jan. 4.

The boil order went into effect Wednesday night for communities west of Highway 78 due to a water main break in a 16-inch pipe. Several areas in the western part of the water works system experienced a loss in water pressure caused by the damage.

""Rigorous testing has been conducted to verify the safety of the drinking water, and all bacteriological samples from the boil water alert area have come back negative. The water is safe to drink throughout the entire service area, and the water quality will be monitored continually,"" the BWWB said in a release issued Friday morning.
All of the communities affected by the alert may now resume normal operations, the BWWB says.

CELEBRATION, Fla. -  A precautionary boil water alert has been issued for the Celebration community and the Enterprise Community Development District
According to the ECDD, the precautionary alert was issued after a disruption to water service. A drop in pressure in water pipes can allow contaminants in.
The ECDD advises that any water used for drinking, cooking, ice, brushing teeth or washing dishes be boiled, or treated to kill any bacteria or viruses that may be in the water.
The ECDD said the boil water advisory is in effect until the district lifts it, which could be several days.
Under a precautionary boil water notice, water used for consumption can be disinfected by any one of the following methods:
• Bringing the water to a rolling boil and holding it there for one (1) minute

• Using a disinfecting chemical.  If you cannot boil water, you should put eight (8) drops of common household bleach which is about 1/8 teaspoon, into one (1) gallon of tap water, shake it, and allow it to stand for 30 minutes before drinking.  If the water is cloudy, use sixteen (16) drops, about 1/4 teaspoon of bleach instead of 8, shake it, and let it stand for 30 minutes.  There should be a slight chlorine odor.  Use common household bleach that has 5% to 6% active ingredients.  Use food grade containers.  Don’t use bleach that has perfume scents added.
• Use water purification tablets or iodine that many sports and camping stores sell.
• You can also buy commercial bottled water for consumption and food preparation.

Consumption includes brushing teeth, washing fruits and vegetables, and homemade ice.  Tap water may be used for showering, baths, shaving and washing, so long as care is taken not to swallow or allow water in eyes or nose or mouth.  Children and disabled individuals should have their baths supervised to ensure water is not ingested.  The time spent bathing should be minimized.  Though the risk of illness is minimal, individuals who have recent surgical wounds, are immune-suppressed, or have a chronic illness may want to consider using bottled or boiled water for cleansing until the notice is lifted.
If you have questions please call (407) 566-4132 during office hours, Monday – Friday, from 8AM—5PM.

Boil Water Advisory For Jacksonville Neighborhood Lifted
Updated: Tue 11:46 PM, Jan 08, 2013
var Title = ""Boil Water Advisory For Jacksonville Neighborhood Lifted""
<a href=""mailto:?subject=Boil Water Advisory For Jacksonville Neighborhood Lifted&amp
The city of Jacksonville says the boil water notice for a section of Brynn Marr has been lifted.
The advisory was issued as a result of repairs that were made to a water line break in Brynn Marr on Brynn Marr road on Monday. The line was repaired.
State regulations require a boil water advisory to be issued if water systems lose pressure. There was no evidence of contamination and testing was performed according to the regulations.
The tests have been completed, and no evidence of contamination was found and therefore the advisory was lifted.
A water line collapse has prompted a boil water advisory for part of one Jacksonville neighborhood.

Those who live in the 600, 700 and 800 blocks of Brynn Marr Road, all of Carolina Circle and all of Meadowview Court are being told they should boil their water for drinking, making ice, brushing teeth and for food preparation. The city says there are about 30 homes affected.
A major water line broke this morning on Brynn Marr Road Monday morning with crews beginning emergency repairs.

Boil water notice issued for Mandeville Tuesday morning
<time aria-label=""Article Published Date and Time"" class=""dateline__published"" datetime=""2013-01- 7T16:17"" id=""dateline__published"">Posted on January  7, 2013 at  4:17 PM</time>
By Heather Nolan, NOLA.com
hnolan@nola.com

The Mandeville Police Department has issued a boil water advisory for residents in the 2300 block of Upton beginning at 9 a.m. Tuesday while the city repairs a water main. The scheduled repair will interrupt water service for about three hours, according to the Police Department.

Residents affected by the repair should boil their water before drinking, making ice, brushing their teeth or using it for food preparation - including rinsing food, according to the notice.

Residents should boil water for one full minute in a clean container. The one minute starts after the water has come to a rolling boil.

The advisory will be lifted once the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals tells Mandeville Public Works that the water is safe.

• University of Louisville taken off probation with accrediting agency

    University of Louisville taken off probation with accrediting agency

    Tuesday, December 5 2017 1:22 PM EST2017-12-05 18:22:02 GMT

    After a year in limbo, the University of Louisville is no longer at risk of losing its accreditation. The university’s accrediting agency, commonly called SACS, revoked U of L’s probationary status after a vote of the agency’s board at its annual meeting in Dallas on Tuesday.

Boil-water advisory given for Meadow Bridge, lifted for Ronceverte

<a class=""fb"" data-new-window-height=""300"" data-new-window-width=""500"" data-tncms-track-event='{""app"":""editorial"",""metric"":""social_share"",""id"":73f4cbd3-0cc1-5f7d-8130-4f9a72e342fe}' data-toggle=""new-window"" data-track='{""network"":""Facebook"",""socialAction"":""post"",""url"":""/news/boil-water-advisory-given-for-meadow-bridge-lifted-for-ronceverte/article_73f4cbd3-0cc1-5f7d-8130-4f9a72e342fe.html""}' href=""https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wvgazettemail.com%2Fnews%2Fboil-water-advisory-given-for-meadow-bridge-lifted-for-ronceverte%2Farticle_73f4cbd3-0cc1-5f7d-8130-4f9a72e342fe.html%3Futm_medium%3Dsocial%26utm_source%3Dfacebook%26utm_campaign%3Duser-share"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""Share on Facebook"">

<a class=""fb"" data-new-window-height=""300"" data-new-window-width=""500"" data-tncms-track-event='{""app"":""editorial"",""metric"":""social_share"",""id"":73f4cbd3-0cc1-5f7d-8130-4f9a72e342fe}' data-toggle=""new-window"" data-track='{""network"":""Facebook"",""socialAction"":""post"",""url"":""/news/boil-water-advisory-given-for-meadow-bridge-lifted-for-ronceverte/article_73f4cbd3-0cc1-5f7d-8130-4f9a72e342fe.html""}' href=""https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wvgazettemail.com%2Fnews%2Fboil-water-advisory-given-for-meadow-bridge-lifted-for-ronceverte%2Farticle_73f4cbd3-0cc1-5f7d-8130-4f9a72e342fe.html%3Futm_medium%3Dsocial%26utm_source%3Dfacebook%26utm_campaign%3Duser-share"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""Share on Facebook"">

CHARLESTON, W.Va. -- A boil-water advisory has been issued for the North Meadow Bridge area of the Meadow Bridge water system. Customers in that area should boil their water for at least one full minute prior to use.The city of Ronceverte has lifted the boil-water advisory for customers in the area of Riverview Cemetery through Teabury Road. They have also lifted the advisory for customers on Chesapeake, Ronceverte and Pocahontas Avenue.

Boil water advisory issued for South Hills

<a class=""fb"" data-new-window-height=""300"" data-new-window-width=""500"" data-tncms-track-event='{""app"":""editorial"",""metric"":""social_share"",""id"":011f8b18-2900-58d1-9e92-be7cec16b171}' data-toggle=""new-window"" data-track='{""network"":""Facebook"",""socialAction"":""post"",""url"":""/news/boil-water-advisory-issued-for-south-hills/article_011f8b18-2900-58d1-9e92-be7cec16b171.html""}' href=""https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wvgazettemail.com%2Fnews%2Fboil-water-advisory-issued-for-south-hills%2Farticle_011f8b18-2900-58d1-9e92-be7cec16b171.html%3Futm_medium%3Dsocial%26utm_source%3Dfacebook%26utm_campaign%3Duser-share"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""Share on Facebook"">

<a class=""fb"" data-new-window-height=""300"" data-new-window-width=""500"" data-tncms-track-event='{""app"":""editorial"",""metric"":""social_share"",""id"":011f8b18-2900-58d1-9e92-be7cec16b171}' data-toggle=""new-window"" data-track='{""network"":""Facebook"",""socialAction"":""post"",""url"":""/news/boil-water-advisory-issued-for-south-hills/article_011f8b18-2900-58d1-9e92-be7cec16b171.html""}' href=""https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wvgazettemail.com%2Fnews%2Fboil-water-advisory-issued-for-south-hills%2Farticle_011f8b18-2900-58d1-9e92-be7cec16b171.html%3Futm_medium%3Dsocial%26utm_source%3Dfacebook%26utm_campaign%3Duser-share"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""Share on Facebook"">

West Virginia American Water issued a precautionary boil water advisory for around 80 customers in the South Hills area of Charleston at about 8:30 p.m. Sunday.The affected areas include all customers who live along Louden Heights, Connel Road, Hampton Road, Stonehenge Road, Sweetbrier Road and Longridge Road. Customers in those areas should boil their water for at least one full minute prior to use until further notice.

Boil advisory lifted for Liberty, Brookfield, Vienna

  • |
  • Print
Tweet
column8:
Published: Sat, January 5, 2013 @ 7:13 p.m.

The Trumbull County sanitary engineer’s department lifted a boil-water advisory for its customers in Liberty, Brookfield and Vienna, east of state Route 11 and north of Churchill Hubbard Road.

The alert was issued Thursday after a break on a 16-inch water line on Niles Vienna Road.

Test samples this afternoon show the water is safe, according to a statement from the sanitary engineer’s department.

column1: Boil water precaution lifted in Fort Lauderdale

January 5, 2013

FORT LAUDERDALE — A precautionary boil water order issued by Broward County for its water and wastewater services customers after a pipe broke mid-week in Fort Lauderdale was lifted Saturday, officials announced.

The water main broke at the intersection of Northwest 31st Avenue and Northwest 26th Street.

Affected customers were in the area east of the break, to Northwest 26th Avenue, and on the block between Northwest 26th Street and Northwest 19th Street. Customers may call during regular business hours at 954-831-3250.—Linda Trischitta

Boil water advisory lifted for portions of Floyd, Harrison Counties

column3:
}
By Sarah Jackson, Digital Content Manager
Email
Connect
sarahjackson@wave3.com

column1: GEORGETOWN, IN (WAVE) – A boil water advisory has been lifted in Floyd and Harrison Counties.
According to the Edwardsville Water Corporation's website, the advisory was lifted on January 7 at 10:30 a.m.
The advisory was issued on January 4 after a water main break on Corydon Ridge Road.

The areas under the advisory were, all of Corydon Ridge Road west of Oak Ridge Drive, Lazy Creek Road, West Oak Court, Oak Ridge Drive, Brookside Drive, Country Lane, Hillside Drive, Oaks Subdivision Section 5, Oaks West Subdivision, Crandall-Lanesville Road, Ponderosa Road, Ferree Road, Walters Road, Raccoon Creek, Woods Drive, John Cook Lane, Green Roe and Baylor Wismann.
Copyright 2013 WAVE News. All rights reserved.
• WAVE 3 NewsNEWSMore>

Sparland water back on: boil order in effect

The water was turned off for all the approximately 200 users about 8 a.m. Friday so major repairs could be done on leaking lines, but the work was done and the water was back on by about 2:30 p.m., said Acting Mayor Debbie Prather.
Village water service was restored Friday afternoon, but the Marshall County community remains under a town-wide boil order.

The water was turned off for all the approximately 200 users about 8 a.m. Friday so major repairs could be done on leaking lines, but the work was done and the water was back on by about 2:30 p.m., said Acting Mayor Debbie Prather.
“They got everything fixed and we’re good to go,” Prather said.

The boil order remains in effect until sampling and testing can be completed. Because the entire system was shut down, it will be necessary to get samples from five areas in different parts of town, and it may be next week before test results can be obtained, said water and sewer operator Stan Sayre.
“We’re hoping to get the results a little sooner,” Prather added. “We’ll let everybody know as soon as we do.”

column1: <h1 class=""entry-title padBtm"">Water main break on Del Prado iepaired
Cape Coral Daily Breeze

A water main break that occurred this morning has been repaired. City crews from the Utilities Department completed the work within a few hours. Only two ""precautionary"" boil water notices were issued the Hess Gas Station and Budget Car Rental businesses. No other customers were impacted from the line break, and there is no boil water advisory for any residents or other businesses in the area.

Information reported that said residents in a 2-block area are under a boil water advisory is incorrect.

Source: City of Cape Coral

UPDATE: Boil water advisory lifted
January 13, 2013 By ACCV Editor

<a class=""qiik-facebook-sharer"" href=""https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://adairvoice.com/boil-water-advisory-in-effect-in-flatwoods-sparksville-breeding-keltner/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""Share on Facebook"">

column3: via=community voice"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""Share on Twitter"">

column1: <a class=""qiik-chat-sharer share-qiikchat-popup"" href=""https://qiikchat.com/sendtodevice/?linkurl=https://adairvoice.com/boil-water-advisory-in-effect-in-flatwoods-sparksville-breeding-keltner/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""Send To Own Devices"">

As of 2:40 p.m. on January 14, 2013 the boil water advisory for residents of the Sparksville, Keltner, Breeding, Flatwoods areas has been lifted by the Division of Water Columbia Office. This means your water is safe for human consumption. You no longer have to boil your water.
A BOIL WATER ADVISORY is in effect for consumers of Columbia Adair Utilities District for customers in Flatwoods, Sparksville, Breeding, and Keltner areas.
The advisory has been issued due to main line leak.
Following such an event, the potential exists for bacteriological contamination of the water supply therefore this Boil Water Advisory has been issued as a precautionary measure.
Until further notice, boil all water used for drinking and cooking, bringing the water to a rolling boil for three minutes before using.
This advisory will remain in effect until the situation has been corrected and test results have shown the water to be of an acceptable quality.
For more information concerning the Boil Water Advisory, contact Lennon Stone at Columbia Adair Utilities District, 270-384-2181.

<a class=""pr"" data-tncms-track-dmp=""Social Media Share"" data-tncms-track-event='{""app"":""editorial"",""metric"":""social_share"",""id"":d33466f6-5ce6-11e2-b7e6-001a4bcf887a}' data-track='{""network"":""Print"",""socialAction"":""print"",""url"":""/news/dpu-lifts-boil-water-advisory/article_d33466f6-5ce6-11e2-b7e6-001a4bcf887a.html""}' href=""javascript:window.print()"" rel=""nofollow"" title=""Print"">
The City of Orangeburg’s Department of Public Utilities says Rowesville water customers no longer need to boil their water prior to drinking or cooking.

Following flushing of the distribution system, bacteriological samples were collected and analyzed by the DPU Water Division. The results indicate that the system is safe to use for drinking and cooking purposes.
Call the DPU Water Division at 803-268-4404 or 803-268-4100 with any questions.

BOIL ADVISORY: Xenia Water Customers Affected
Posted 3:33 pm, January 11, 2013, by Kelly Maricle, Updated at 03:46PM, January 11, 2013

• Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Google
  • Email
  • Reddit
  • Tumblr
This is an archived article and the information in the article may be outdated. Please look at the time stamp on the story to see when it was last updated.
BOIL ADVISORY: Xenia Water Customers Affected
The Xenia Rural Water District is warning some of its customers of a water main break that is prompting a boil advisory.

Customers who live east of the Des Moines River in Hamilton and Webster Counties, those north of the city of Boone, and customers surrounding Story City are advised to boil their water before drinking or using in cooking.
Xenia says a water main break Friday caused the problem and they are working on repairs.
Water must be boiled for at least one minute and cooled before it is safe to drink or use for food preparation. The water is still safe to use for bathing and laundry.
Testing will be done after repairs are completed to make sure the water is safe. Xenia will let residents know when the boil advisory is lifted.
A detailed map of the customers affected can be found

Quail Valley Boil Water Alert Lifted
A boil water advisory issued Wednesday for residents in part of Quail Valley has been lifted.
By Shireese Bell, Patch Staff | Jan 11, 2013 4:30 pm ET

column2: url=https%3A//patch.com/south-carolina/irmo/quail-valley-boil-water-alert-lifted"" target=""_blank"" title=""Tweet"" trigger=""twitter"">
column3: t=Quail%20Valley%20Boil%20Water%20Alert%20Lifted"" target=""_blank"" title=""Post on Google+"" trigger=""google_plus"">
column4: title=Quail%20Valley%20Boil%20Water%20Alert%20Lifted"" target=""_blank"" title=""Post on Reddit"" trigger=""reddit"">
column5: body=Quail%20Valley%20Boil%20Water%20Alert%20Lifted%0D%0A%0D%0AA%20boil%20water%20advisory%20issued%20Wednesday%20for%20residents%20in%20part%20of%20Quail%20Valley%20has%20been%20lifted.%0D%0A%0D%0Ahttps://patch.com/south-carolina/irmo/quail-valley-boil-water-alert-lifted"" title=""Send Email"" trigger=""email"">0

column1:
The boil water advisory issued for the Quail Valley area near Harbison has been lifted. 

Residents no longer have to boil water for use after Columbia Water Works crews fixed an 8-inch water line break.

The area under the alert included water customers of Brandywine Drive, Quail Valley East from Brandywine Drive to Quail Valley West, Quail Valley West from Deer Trail to Quail Valley East, Beaver Dam Road from Deer Trail to Railfence Drive, and Railfence Drive. 

Officials said bacteriological samples collected and analyzed after an intense flushing of the distribution system indicate the water is safe to use for drinking and cooking.

For questions concerning the advisory, call 803-733-8336 or 803-781-2181.

   Subscribe
